name: Tiramisù
description: /'Pick me up'/ The tiramisù is an Italian dessert that combines dry biscuits soaked in coffee with a mascarpone cheese and egg cream, and a note of bitter cocoa on top. It's one of the world's most famous desserts, and with reason; it's both extremely simple to make and delicious.
instructions: - Whip the yolks (whites are excess) with the sugar until it develops soft peaks.
- Incorporate the mascarpone, whip slowly then faster for 3 minutes. Cream shouldn't be pourable, but consistent.
- Spread thin layer of cream on the bottom to avoid coffee leaks.
- Dip the ladyfingers once on the coffee, quickly, drain them vertically and place them.
- Add cream until the Savoiardi are hidden, repeat for 3 layers of ladyfingers. With each layer, turn them 90º.
- Finally, add cacao powder on top.
variants: Substitute the Savoiardi for pan di Spagna (bizcocho, Spanish sponge cake)

culinary: Using these quantities, I've tried 4 layers of 4 Savoiardi each, but in my opinion it's better to stay at 3: the cream layers become thicker, and the Tiramisù stays perfectly balanced.
Coffee from an Espresso machine, and even from a well brewed Moka, is too strong. Dilute respectively with x3 and x1 as much water as there is coffee.
Be sure to learn how to brew coffee in a Moka without bitterness for this recipe. It makes a world of difference.
It's a sin to throw away the whites! Conserve them in the fridge. They are high in protein and can be added to scrambled eggs, used for Amaretti biscuits, etc.
serving: Tiramisù is best served as squares or rectangles.
